questions.question:
Question 1: A patient presented with the following finding. Which of the following can cause this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The finding seen in the given image is pitting edema. Edema can be caused by elevated 
hydrostatic pressure and reduced colloid osmotic pressure. Under normal circumstances, there is little net movement of fluid out of vessels due to the balance 
of: • Vascular hydrostatic pressure which has the tendency to push water and salts out of capillaries 
into the interstitial space • Plasma osmotic pressure or colloid oncotic pressure which has a tendency to pull water and salts 
back into vessels. The pressure dynamics seen inside a capillary is given below. Atarterial end 
Atvenous end Capillary hydrostatic pressur 
e = 15-20 mmHg Capillary hydrostatic pressur 
e = 30-35 mmHg Osmotic Pressure = 25 mmH 
g Osmotic Pressure = 25 mmH 
g Hydrostatic Pressure < Osmo 
tic Pressure Fluid moves in 
to the capillary Hydrostatic Pressure > Osmo 
tic Pressure Fluid moves o 
utof the capillary 128 
Sold by @itachibot Many pathologic disorders are associated with an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure or a 
decrease in plasma osmotic pressure, which lead to edema.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false about transudate?

options.a: It is a non-inflammatory edema or effusion
options.b: It is a protein-poor and cell-poor fluid
options.c: It has a specific gravity of less than 1.012
options.d: It is caused by increased vascular permeability

questions.explanation:
Transudate results from increased fluid pressures or diminished oncotic forces in the plasma and 
is not due to increased vascular permeability. There are 2 types of extravascular fluid - transudate and exudate These differences are depicted in the image below. Transudate 
Exudate Non-inflammatory edema 
Inflammatory edema Ultrafiltrate of plasma 
Increasedvascular permeabili 
tycaused by inflammatory me 
diators High (>3g/dl) protein content Low protein content (<3g/dl) 
, mainly albumin No tendency to coagulate 
Coagulates readily due to hig 
h content of fibrinogen Low specific gravity (<1.012) 
High specific gravity (>1.018) Low LDH levels 
High LDH levels High cell count Low cell count (< 500-1000/ 
µL) Eg. Edema in congestive card 
iac failure Eg. Pus 129 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 121 
Sold by @itachibot In which of the following conditions does edema result from decreased colloidal osmotic 
pressure?
questions.explanation:
In nephrotic syndrome, edema occurs due to massive proteinuria that leads to a decrease in 
plasma colloid osmotic pressure. The common causes of reduced plasma osmotic pressure are conditions that cause inadequate 
synthesis or increased loss of albumin (mainly) and other plasma proteins from circulation. These 
conditions include: • Protein-losing glomerulopathies (nephrotic syndrome) • Liver cirrhosis (ascites) • Malnutrition • Protein-losing gastroenteropathy Edema can also occur due to increased hydrostatic pressure as a result of impaired venous return. 
This is seen in conditions like: • Congestive heart failure • Deep venous thrombosis • Renal artery stenosis

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not true?

options.a: Periorbital edema is seen in severe renal disease
options.b: Pitting edema occurs due to edema in subcutaneous tissues
options.c: Exudative effusions are typically protein-rich and cloudy
options.d: Chylous peritoneal effusion is an example of an exudate

questions.explanation:
Chylous peritoneal effusion caused by the lymphatic blockage is an example of a transudate. Transudative effusions are typically protein-poor, translucent, and straw-colored. However, there 
may be certain exceptions like chylous peritoneal effusions which may be milky due to the 
presence of lipids absorbed from the gut. 130 
Sold by @itachibot Exudative effusions are protein-rich and often cloudy due to the presence of WBCs. Subcutaneous edema has the following features: • Dependent edema - dependent areas (towards gravity) have high hydrostatic pressures i.e., in 
the legs when standing and the sacrum when recumbent • Pitting edema - finger pressure over markedly edematous subcutaneous tissue displaces the 
interstitial fluid and leaves a depression. Edema resulting from renal dysfunction often appears initially in parts of the body containing 
loose connective tissue, such as the eyelids. Thus, periorbital edema is a characteristic finding in 
severe renal disease.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is false?

options.c: Arteriolar dilation is seen in hyperemia.

questions.explanation:
Hyperemia is seen in inflammation, not congestion. The differences between hyperemia and congestion are summarised below: Hyperemia 
Congestion Active process due to arteriol 
ar dilation Passive process due to impair 
ed venous outflow Edema is absent 
Edema is present Red color of the tissues 
Blue-red color of the tissue (d 
ue to deoxyhemoglobin) Seen in inflammation 
Seen in right heart failure an 
d portal venous obstruction i 
n cirrhosis

questions.question:
Question 6: An 82-year-old man presents to the ER with fever and tachycardia since last night. On 
examination, he is drowsy, his BP is 92/54 mmHg and his temperature is 103 °F. His wife 
tells you he had been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection 5 days ago for which he had 
been prescribed antibiotics. He is a known case of colon cancer and also has a history of 
myocardial infarction 6 months ago. What type of shock is he likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating 
from a urinary tract infection. Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the 
release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of 
events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume 
into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion. Other types of shock are: • Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction • Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold 
shock • Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid loss 131 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: What is the first step of hemostasis?

options.d: Binding of platelets to exposed vWF

questions.explanation:
The first step of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction. The normal process of hemostasis is as follows: • Arteriolar vasoconstriction - After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce transient 
vasoconstriction. • Primary hemostasis - The various steps involved in this process are: • Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed 
extracellular matrix (ECM) • Activation of platelets which undergo a change in shape and release their granules • Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet 
aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen • Formation of the primary platelet plug • Secondary hemostasis - Local activation of the coagulation cascade involving tissue factor and 
platelet phospholipids results in fibrin polymerization, cementing the platelets into a definitive 
secondary hemostatic plug. • Clot stabilization and resorption - Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue 
plasminogen activator (tPA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic 
process to the site of injury.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following coagulation factors is bound and activated by tissue factor?
questions.explanation:
The tissue factor binds and activates factor VII. Tissue factor is produced by the subendothelial cells in the vessel wall such as vascular smooth 
muscle cells and fibroblasts. It is a membrane-bound procoagulant glycoprotein. Secondary hemostasis involves a sequence of events, which results in the polymerization of fibrin. 
This is achieved by cross-linking fibrin monomers into insoluble strands that serve to stabilize the 
loose platelet clot formed in primary hemostasis. 132 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not found in -granules of platelets?
questions.explanation:
Serotonin is present in the dense or delta() granules of the platelets, not alpha() granules. Platelets are disc-shaped, anucleate cell fragments that are released from the megakaryocytes in 
the bone marrow into the bloodstream. The functions of these platelets depend on 
their glycoprotein receptors, contractile cytoskeleton, and cytoplasmic granules. There are two types of cytoplasmic granules present in platelets: • Alpha granules • Dense or delta granules -granules contain: • Adhesion molecule P-selectin on their membranes 133 
Sold by @itachibot • Proteins involved in coagulation like - • Fibrinogen • Coagulation factor V • vWF • Protein factors involved in wound healing like - • Fibronectin • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin-binding chemokine) • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) • Transforming growth factor  (TGF  ) -granules contain: • Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) • Ionized calcium • Serotonin • Epinephrine

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with prolonged bleeding is found to have vitamin K deficiency. The function of 
which of the following clotting factors would be unaffected in this condition?
questions.explanation:
A deficiency of vitamin K does not alter the function of factor V. Vitamin K is required as a cofactor for the -carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, and X. Calcium 
binds to -carboxylated glutamic acid residues that are present in these factors during clotting. This action of vitamin K is antagonized by drugs such as warfarin, which is widely used as an 
anticoagulant.

questions.question:
Question 11: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin 
time assay?
questions.explanation:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic 
pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test. The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen. In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., 
ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, 
and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the function of thrombomodulin?
questions.explanation:
Thrombomodulin is an anticoagulant. 134 
Sold by @itachibot It is produced by all endothelial cells except those in cerebral microcirculation. It binds to 
thrombin on the endothelial cell surface. When bound in this complex, thrombin loses its ability 
to activate coagulation factors and platelets, and instead cleaves and activates protein C. Activated 
protein C/protein S complex is a potent inhibitor of coagulation factors Va and VIIIa. This action 
results in an anticoagulant effect. The effect of recombinant thrombomodulin administration in sepsis-induced coagulopathy and 
DIC is being studied currently. Other important anticoagulant substances are: • Antithrombin III - It inhibits the activity of thrombin and other factors like XIIa, XIa, Xa, and 
IXa. It is activated by binding to heparin-like molecules. • Proteins C and S - These proteins are vitamin K–dependent proteins that inactivate factors Va 
and VIIIa. • Endothelial prostacyclin (PGI2) and nitric oxide (NO) - These are potent vasodilators and 
inhibitors of platelet aggregation. • Tissue factor pathway inhibitor - This is derived from the endothelium and inhibits tissue factor 
VIIa and Xa molecules.

questions.question: Question 13: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.explanation:
Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V. This is named after the 
city in The Netherlands where it was discovered. Of the inherited causes of hypercoagulability, point mutations in the factor V gene and 
prothrombin gene are the most common.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a part of Virchow's triad?
questions.explanation:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia 
vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis. Virchow's triad in thrombosis: • Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability. • Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury. • Hypercoagulability of blood These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.

questions.question: Question 15: In which of the following structures are lines of Zahn seen?
questions.explanation:
Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn. These 
are formed by pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell-rich layers. 135 
Sold by @itachibot They signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood. Their presence can therefore 
distinguish antemortem clots from the nonlaminated postmortem clots. The below histopathological image of a thrombus shows these alternating bands called lines of 
Zahn.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following do chicken fat clots refer to?
questions.explanation:
Chicken fat clots refer to post-mortem clots i.e., clots that are formed after death. Postmortem clots are gelatinous and have a dark red (currant jelly) dependent portion where red 
cells have settled by gravity and a yellow (chicken fat) upper portion due to coagulation of plasma. Antemortem clots can be differentiated from postmortem clots by: • Presence of lines of Zahn 136 
Sold by @itachibot • Attachment to the underlying vessel wall

questions.question: Question 17: Saddle embolus is seen in which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation:
An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses and are the most common form 
of thromboembolic disease. In more than 95% of cases, PE originates from leg deep vein 
thrombi (DVTs). Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side 
of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Depending on the size of 
the embolus, it can have 3 fates: • It can occlude the main pulmonary artery • It can straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus) • It can pass out into the smaller, branching arteries The CT image given below shows a saddle embolus lodged in the main pulmonary artery 
extending into both its limbs as indicated by the red arrows.

questions.question:
Question 18: Following autopsy, an H&E stained specimen of the lung was obtained which is given 
below. What could be the likely cause of death? 125 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary 
arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE). 137 
Sold by @itachibot AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse 
and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of 
amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or 
rupture of uterine veins. Findings at autopsy include: • Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of- • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin • Lanugo hair • Fat from vernix caseosa • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract • Marked pulmonary edema • Diffuse alveolar damage • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not seen in patients with DIC?
questions.explanation:
Increased prothrombin time (PT) is a feature of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic 
thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence, which leads to the formation of 
microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic 
diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, 
activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms. Laboratory investigations in DIC reveal the following: 138 
Sold by @itachibot • Thrombocytopenia • Prolonged prothrombin time (PT)/thrombin time (TT) • Decreased fibrinogen level • Elevated levels of fibrin-split products (D-dimers)

questions.question: Question 20: Red infarcts do not occur in which of the following organs?
questions.explanation:
White infarcts occur in the spleen, not red infarcts. Red infarcts occur in the following conditions: • Venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion) • Loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone • Tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an 
unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone • Tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow • When flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following 
angioplasty of an arterial obstruction) The below image shows a hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary red infarct. White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., 
heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining 
capillary beds into the necrotic area. The below image shows a sharply demarcated white infarct in the spleen. 139 
Sold by @itachibot Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize or when microbes seed 
necrotic tissue. In these cases, the infarct is converted into an abscess, with a correspondingly 
greater inflammatory response.

questions.question:
Question 21: A bridge construction worker presents with generalized bone pain. He is found to have 
ischemic necrosis of bilateral femoral heads, left tibia, and right humerus. Caisson disease is 
suspected. What is this condition related to?
questions.explanation:
Caisson disease is a chronic form of decompression sickness which occurs when individuals 
experience a sudden decrease in atmospheric pressure. It is named after the pressurized vessels that are used in bridge construction as workers in these 
vessels are known to suffer from both acute and chronic forms of decompression sickness. When air is breathed at high pressure, increased amounts of gas, particularly nitrogen, are 
dissolved in the blood and tissues. If there is a sudden fall in pressure, the nitrogen comes out of 
the solution in the tissues and the blood and forms gas emboli. In Caisson disease, the persistence 
of gas emboli in the skeletal system leads to the development of multiple foci of ischemic necrosis. 
The more common sites are the femoral heads, tibia, and humeri.

questions.question:
Question 22: Chest X-ray of a 60-year-old woman with dyspnoea at rest revealed right-sided pleural 
effusion. A pleural fluid analysis was done. Which of the following findings would rule out a 
transudative cause?
questions.explanation:
High plasma protein content in the pleural fluid would rule out a transudative cause. In a 
transudative effusion, the fluid has low protein content, little or no cellular material, and low 
specific gravity. It is essentially an ultrafiltrate of the blood plasma. It is produced as a result of osmotic or 
hydrostatic imbalance across the vessel wall. There is no increase in vascular permeability. The table below gives the differences between transudative and exudative effusion. 140 
Sold by @itachibot Features 
Transudate 
Exudate Process 
Passive (increased pressure) 
Active (inflammation) Vascular permeability

Low S.G<1.012Low protein 
High S.G>1.020High prot 
ein Fibrin

Absent 
Present 141 
Sold by @itachibot Modes of Inheritance
